posts.name: James Blair
posts.cooked:
We spent all evening failing to configure the radio with the latest FRC Radio Configuration Tool on a Windows 10 computer connected to the radio with an ethernet cable and an external power supply.  We never got past the bridge failure, could not connect to expected IP address, etc. Tried loading the firmware. Tried configuring the radio.555555555 Tried disabling all the PC ports except the ethernet. Tried swapping out the Ethernet cable. Tried turning off the firewall. Tried running application as Administrator. Tried various combinations of plugging and unplugging the radio and ethernet cable and waiting between 30 seconds and two minutes.

If anyone knows the secret, please share.  You can call me an idiot and I’d believe it.  I am beginning to rethink all my life decisions.

posts.name: vargoose84
posts.cooked: tried disabling wifi?

posts.name: Ross Hagglund
posts.cooked:
I think this is the same issue I hit every year,  until I remember that I need to DISABLE all the network devices other than the ethernet port I’m using to talk with the radio.  I don’t think you can just disable the port, I think the device has to be disabled, if the device still exists it fails.

I think the root cause is whoever wrote the flashing tool just takes the first active network device, and that usually is the bluetooth network.

I am interested in the eventual answer as I get to watch our students flash our radios on Thursday and I’d like to appear wise by already knowing the solution O:)

posts.name: James Blair
posts.cooked:
Thank you for your responses.

We tried disabling the port in Windows internet and Sharing (and also putting the WIFI into airplane mode), but we have not yet tried going into the devices settings and disabling the WIFI device.

Another thing we read is that certain Java updates can cause failures.  We will look into that next.

We will let you know what happens tonight.

We have never had these problems connecting to the RoboRIO (except the 2.0 version, which is a totally different monster), only with configuring the radio.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked: Just to be clear, the radio programming instructions link to roboRIO Network Troubleshooting — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation and say to disable all other network adapters. So not just wifi, but bluetooth, vpn, vEthernet, etc.

posts.name: James Blair
posts.cooked:
We were successful in configuring the radio… but we still have no idea what the problem was with the configuration tool or how to avoid it in the future.

After a second night of unsuccessful attempts at disabling large numbers of devices on the computer and bouncing the radio multiple times during the process and looking for problematic Java updates, the kids got fed up and just started plugging the radio into different computers.  The fourth one was able to configure it successfully… without disabling any devices (I think all they did was turn off the WIFI).

So the kids using random attempts were able to find a solution in one quarter of the time I spent unsuccessfully trying to diagnose and solve the problem.  So what is the lesson we should take away from this experience?

So I can give some common issues. The whole Radio config is a mess and has been for years. I always look forward to the long line of people trying to config their radios at a competition lol.

First, the port they show to plug in the ethernet doesn’t really matter. Plug into either one, try it, switch it, it’s a process. I usually prefer the one it says NOT to plug in lol. Second, don’t use PoE injection. The power delivery and the Ethernet should be separate cables. When you power cycle the radio, use the power cable to do so. Third, as some have mentioned, you have to disable every hardware connection. Wireless, Bluetooth especially, and if you have a VPN uninstall it even. Fourth, sometimes, when resetting the firmware, you don’t need to power cycle the radio when the power LED is blinking. I have no idea why, as it tells you to cycle power when the LED is blinking, but sometime you just don’t. Usually you always need the initial power cycle, and sometime you need another, sometimes you don’t, even though the LED blinks. Fifth, sometimes it’s the cable as you mentioned, however this can be tested easily by plugging it into something else.

link_counts.title: Programming your Radio — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: Oh! And sometimes the config tool will get “stuck” if you launched it with another adapter still turned on and then turned that adapter off while it was still running. Make sure to restart the config app after tuning system settings or change the settings before launching it.

posts.name: James Blair
posts.cooked:
Thank you all for your input.  It has really helped put together a general picture of what is going on with the radio configuration tool.

Now, I am just a software guy and not a real engineer, but this looks like a system that is in a state of disrepair.  It looks like the tool was originally designed to operate in a much simpler environment.  Changes in computers and the operating system have increased the complexity of the system but the reliability of the configuration program has not increased.  Unpredictable results are increasing to the point that the instructions and troubleshooting tips include essentially trying a bunch of random stuff.

This issue is not going to get better by itself.  Without an upgrade of the configuration tool, it will only slowly get worse until it stops working completely.

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked:
There’s some weird power on timing that I can tell you and this timing depending on certain radio.  Here’s the general thing you need to do:

Disconnected everything from the Radio. (no power, no any ethernet cable)

Starts the ‘Flash Firmware’ on the Computer while nothing is connected (disable WiFi and make sure Ethernet port is Enabled and Set to DHCP).  Plug in 1 end of the Ethernet Cable to your computer.

Wait for the Prompt to tell you to power up the Radio.

Only using the 12V power plug (I have all sorts of issues with certain PoE so I always program the radio using 12V power plug).

Plug in the power plug -

on some older radio, I have to wait until the BLUE light finish flashing.

on some other radio, I only need to wait about 30s after the BLUE light comes on.

At this point, plug in the other end of the Ethernet into the Radio to the Port closest to the Power Port.

Wait for the computer to pickup the ethernet port.  [If it fails then change your # 5 timing to the other one].

Once you have flash it, PROGRAM it with your team’s number (and Name it - if you plan on having multiple radio all being on at the same time, name each radio differently - TeamNum_Dev, TeamNum_Main1, etc.

Good Luck.

posts.name: connor.worley
posts.cooked: Which version of Java is installed on the failing machines?

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
YMMV, if you try this, you should probably redo the firmware and config using the official kiosk before you use the radio at an event, caveat emptor, etc.

I had trouble as well this year, when most years, things seem to have worked fine for me.  I dug into things a little, and things got way better for me when I updated a package called npcap .  There is a version of this bundled with the radio utility install, but it seems to be quite old.  You can install the newer version over top of the existing one.

It may make a difference which version of the NDIS specification is used by the driver for your network device.  The newer versions of npcap support newer versions of NDIS, plus include several bug fixes.

link_counts.title: Npcap: Windows Packet Capture Library & Driver

posts.name: codedr
posts.cooked:
One problem with re-programming the radio is that radio is only re-programmable in a small window when it is first  powered on.

The utility works by sending the protocol packets on the ethernet interface that the radio looks for in the small boot interval.

Hints for a successful imaging:

make sure all the network interfaces are disabled except the required ethernet

connect ethernet with the radio powered off

start the radio configure utility

navigate to the program radio menu and setup all parameters

plug in radio power

push start in the utility

posts.name: Doug Washington
posts.cooked: This is certainly the solution to the problem people are facing with respect to the bridge failure/NPF error . It looks like the radio config installer just looks to see if  npcap is installed and, if it is, it doesn’t bother upgrading. Our team laptops had various versions npcap across them (0.999x - 1.30) with each laptop popping up the error when attempting to update the firmware (Configuring the radios worked fine, though.) I upgraded them to npcap 1.60 and everything worked fine.
